results.title: A Founder of Odwalla Tries to Recapture His Mojo
results.abstract: With tough times in the 1990s behind him, the head of Califia Farms has a new idea: nut milk and coffees.

multimedia.caption: Greg Steltenpohl at the Downtown Los Angeles headquarters of his new beverage company, Califia Farms. Mr. Steltenpohl started Odwalla, his first company, with members of his former band.

results.title: Wall Street Extends Rally but Germany Truck Deaths Reduce Gains
results.abstract: Wall Street extended a recent rally on Monday but finished the session short of earlier highs after several people were killed by a truck driven into a Christmas market in Germany.

results.title: A Food Industry Study Tries to Discredit Advice About Sugar
results.abstract: The review elicited sharp criticism from public health experts because the authors have ties to the food and sugar industries.

results.title: Christine Lagarde, I.M.F. Chief, Is Found Guilty of Negligence
results.abstract: The judges did not impose a fine or jail time in the case, linked to Ms. Lagarde’s time as France’s finance minister, but the verdict adds to the debate over the International Monetary Fund’s role.
results.byline: By LIZ ALDERMAN, AURELIEN BREEDEN and LANDON THOMAS Jr.

results.title: Guilty Verdict for I.M.F. Chief Christine Lagarde: A Primer
results.abstract: Ms. Lagarde was not punished, but her position as head of the International Monetary Fund is on shaky ground.

results.abstract: Federal prosecutors in Brooklyn contend that executives overvalued the assets that Platinum invested in and misrepresented the performance of certain funds.

results.title: Yellen Tells College Graduates That Value of a Degree Is Rising
results.abstract: Janet Yellen’s speech at the University of Baltimore underscored the Federal Reserve’s satisfaction with an economic expansion that is in its eighth year.

multimedia.caption: Janet Yellen, the Federal Reserve chairwoman, giving a commencement address at the University of Baltimore. “A college diploma or an advanced degree is a key to economic success,” she told graduates.

results.title: Harnessing the U.S. Taxpayer to Fight Cancer and Make Profits
results.abstract: Public funding is backing a new immunotherapy treatment, but the bulk of any profits will go to a private company. So are taxpayers getting a good deal?
results.byline: By MATT RICHTEL and ANDREW POLLACK

multimedia.caption: Dr. Steven Rosenberg, left, who has led the surgery branch at the National Cancer Institute for 42 years, and Dr. Arie Belldegrun, the founder of Kite Pharma.

results.title: Snapchat Plays Hard to Get With Celebrities and Influencers

results.title: In India, a Clash at the Top of the Tata Empire Gets Ugly
results.abstract: Ratan Tata, a revered figure in a country steeped in corruption, finds himself caught up in a public fight for control of the business amid allegations of wrongdoing.

multimedia.caption: The Taj Mahal Palace Hotel in Mumbai, India. The founder of the Tata Group, Jamsetji Tata, opened the hotel, India’s first luxury lodging serving Indians, in the early 1900s. Today it is considered a national landmark.
multimedia.copyright: Atul Loke for The New York Times

multimedia.caption: The Taj Mahal Palace Hotel in Mumbai, India. The founder of the Tata Group, Jamsetji Tata, opened the hotel, India’s first luxury lodging serving Indians, in the early 1900s. Today it is considered a national landmark.

results.title: Fewer Journalists Were Killed on the Job This Year, Group Reports
results.abstract: But the Committee to Protect Journalists said those killed unintentionally in combat accounted for a majority of the deaths for the first time since 1992.

results.title: Let 2017 Be the Year of Working Hard and Resting Hard
results.abstract: Make it a priority to be human again — to work hard and to rest hard without worrying that we’ll fail at life if we rest, a financial planner writes.

results.title: In Spain, New Restaurants Nourish the Needy, and the Soul
results.abstract: At four new restaurants named Robin Hood, poor people are served by waiters, helping them regain a sense of dignity that is hard to achieve when eating in a soup kitchen.

multimedia.caption: The Robin Hood restaurant in Madrid this month. The restaurant is one of four with the same name that have opened in the past month in Spain to serve those who cannot afford to dine out.

results.title: Forget ‘Pat the Bunny.’ My Child Is Reading Hemingway.
results.abstract: Some publishers are repurposing modern classics, making simplified picture books of them for children and cutting out the R-rated details.

results.title: Free Cash in Finland. Must Be Jobless.
results.abstract: Finland will soon hand out cash to 2,000 jobless people, free of bureaucracy or limits on side earnings. The idea, universal basic income, is gaining traction worldwide.

results.title: Climate Change News That Stuck With Us in 2016
results.abstract: Here’s a selection of Times reporters’ most memorable stories of the year, with a focus on climate change and related environmental issues.

results.title: Whistle-Blowers Spur Companies to Change Their Ways
results.abstract: Financial wrongdoing dropped — and stayed down — at companies that were subject to investigations, a new study shows.

multimedia.caption: Boxes were wheeled into court in 2002 when Arthur Andersen was charged with destroying documents in the Enron investigation. The Sarbanes-Oxley law, a reaction to cases like Enron’s, gave new protection to whistle-blowers.
multimedia.copyright: James Nielsen/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
